When the Lights Go Out (Again), These Lanterns Keep Going

Look, we both know the drill. Your family calls, the power's been out for six hours, and they're navigating the kitchen with a phone flashlight that's about to die. Sending a good rechargeable lantern isn't just thoughtful—it's genuinely life-changing during those endless apagones. The catch? Not every lantern survives Cuba's humidity, and some burn through batteries faster than a Havana taxi burns through gas. I've dug through the options so you don't have to.

Here's what actually matters when you're shopping for lanterns headed to Cuba: runtime is everything. A lantern that looks impressive on paper but dies after four hours is useless when blackouts stretch through the night. You also want multiple charging options—USB is standard, but solar backup is clutch when the grid's been down for days and there's nowhere to plug in.

The other thing nobody tells you? Weight matters for shipping costs. A chunky lantern might seem more "serious," but if it pushes your package over the weight limit, you're paying extra for no real benefit. The sweet spot is something lightweight, bright enough to actually illuminate a room (not just a closet), and built to handle humidity without corroding in six months.

I've tested these against real Cuban conditions—not camping-in-Vermont conditions. There's a difference.

The Short Version

For most families in Cuba, the Glocusent 135 LED is the one to send. Up to 200 hours of runtime, three color temperatures (warm light for evenings, bright white for cooking), and a 5000mAh battery that doubles as a phone charger. It's the workhorse.

Plus, the 5000mAh battery can charge a phone in a pinch. SOS mode included for emergencies.

Quick Tips Before You Ship

  • → Charge it first. Send the lantern fully charged so your family can use it immediately—the first blackout after arrival is always the worst timing.
  • → Include the USB cable. Sounds obvious, but cables get lost in shipping chaos. Tape it to the lantern.
  • → Solar backup = peace of mind. If the grid's down for days, solar charging becomes the only option. Prioritize lanterns with this feature.
  • → Skip the cheapest options. That $8 lantern on Amazon? It'll corrode in Cuban humidity within months. Spend a little more.

The Bottom Line

For most families, the Glocusent 135 LED is the smart choice—200 hours of runtime, phone charging capability, and enough brightness to actually be useful. If you want to cover the whole house without breaking the bank, grab the XTAUTO 4-pack with solar charging. Either way, you're sending something that'll genuinely make those long blackout nights more bearable.

Your family will thank you the next time UNE decides to take the night off.
